body:
It looks like this is a bug in the fuse library rclone is using.  I've reported an issue: https://github.com/bazil/fuse/issues/194

I couldn't see an easy fix though!

This is now fixed here

https://beta.rclone.org/v1.40-113-gd36b80f5/ (uploaded in 15-30 mins)

which will be in [the latest beta](https://beta.rclone.org) from now on and 1.41.

Still encountering this with 1.41 and 1.42b

```
root@air:/mnt/gdrive# rclone -V; df -i /mnt/gdrive
rclone v1.42-001-g71103495Î²
- os/arch: linux/amd64
- go version: go1.10.1
Filesystem         Inodes IUsed      IFree IUse% Mounted on
gdrive:        1000000000     0 1000000000    0% /mnt/gdrive
root@air:/mnt/gdrive#
```

I have mounted it with the new binary, but I haven't changed anything else. Is there any way I could be using the old version? I had 1.35 installed via .sh script before, and I had to manually `rm /usr/sbin/rclone` before the script would install the latest version.
@chauffer which provider are you using? Not all support this feature.
@ncw Google Drive, apologies for not including it, I thought it was obvious from the name ðŸ˜‡

@chauffer probably should have been obvious :-)  Is it a team drive?  If so then team drives don't support reading the size used and the size free alas.

What does `rclone about gdrive:` say?

@ncw I'm getting:

```
root@air:~# rclone about gdrive
2018/06/17 18:35:36 Failed to about: About call failed: failed to read disk usage: no such file or directory
```
Both before & after having it mounted with this cmd

```
root@air:~# rclone mount --allow-non-empty --allow-other --max-read-ahead 200M gdrive:/ /mnt/gdrive
```
It is not a team drive, but it is a G Suite individual drive

EDIT: My bad ðŸ˜… 
```
root@air:~# rclone about gdrive:
Used:    2.307T
Trashed: 46.109G
Other:   97.209G
```

> df -i /mnt/gdrive
Filesystem         Inodes IUsed      IFree IUse% Mounted on
gdrive:        1000000000     0 1000000000    0% /mnt/gdrive

This output looks correct to me. It shows 0 inodes in use and `0%` usage.

The original issue was the display of `100%` usage.
Thanks @B4dM4n for setting me and @chauffer straight - I was looking at the 0 readings having failed to notice that this was about inodes :blush:
